page.title: 03AGRICULTURE IN HEADCORN
page.content: There has been a gradual{change}in the farming pattern of the district in the last 20 years. Hops,which once were very common,now are only found in one or two fields and the oast houses have been converted to housing.{Orchards too are diminishing,both in acreage and in the size of tree.{Arable crops such as wheat have replaced the orchards that have been grubbed. Others have had their large spreading traditional trees replaced by smaller but easier to pick varieties.{Dairy} {farming }is now non-existent in this area. The last dairy farm was given over to arable in 1984. There is still a good deal of{grazing}for both sheep and horses but the trend is generally towards arable,fortunately without too much hedge-row removal. There are two large scale{egg production units.}Both use the "battery" method.
